bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, June 5, 1923

div1.p: Connor comments on Carter's paper on the epidemiology of yellow fever. Connor discusses his work on malaria and yellow fever in Mexico. He mentions the resignation of Guiteras.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, June 5, 1923
div1.opener:
PODERI EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
MEXICO
DEPARTAMENTO
DE
SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA.
----
COMISION ESPECIAL PARA LA CAMPAÑA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA.
----
JEFATURA EN COLIMA.
SEXTA ZONA.
----
Colima, Col., June 5-1923
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have twice read your Epidemiology
section of your forthcoming work on yellow fever.
If I may criticize it will be to point out that I could
find no reference to the fact that yellow fever in
endemic centres, such as cities and fair sized towns, is
as a general rule circumscribed. It was in Guayaquil and
I think it was in Merida and as I remember the situation
the same is true for Panama. Of Havana I have no personal
knowledge and have never seen a spot-map of cases record-
ed in that city.

I am enclosing my section on epi-
demiology which I have in mind to develope into an artic-
le on yellow fever in Mexico to be read at the annual
yellow fever convention during the latter part of this
year.

I am wondering if it will take up
too much of your time to read over the enclosed notes and
to let me have your criticism of same. There is nothing
new in these notes and my thought all through has been to
emphasize certain points in the epidemiology of yellow fe-
ver which I have learned from experience that the average
Latin physician overlooks. I think you will agree with me
that for the most part physicians in Latin America when
occupying a position in the Health Department regards the
work in coonection therewith as of minor importance and
will rarely if ever take the time to read up on the subject
and this is especially true regarding epidemiology.

The paper which I have in mind will
briefly relate the history of yellow fever in Mexico foll-
owed by the epidemiology of this infection then some facts
concerning the aedes egypti concluding the article with a
description of the anti-larvae measures as practised in the
present campaign.
Dr. Carter
June 5-1923

Your suggestion to treat Lejias (aguas de ceniza) with
a soap solution is a practical one and will be tried out in the
Colima area and brought to the attention of our men in other Zones
where Lejia is in general use.

I wonder if I wrote you that Doctor Hernandez of Merida,
Yucatan, and Doctor Iglesias of Veracruz have been granted fellow-
ship by our Board for technical training at the Institute under
Noguchi. This training will consist for the most part in making
practical demonstrations in Pfeiffer tests. Unfortunately, we
have not been able as yet to find a physician for the Tampico
area that would be acceptáble to Doctor Noguchi for training but
we hope that Doctor Perrin of Mexico City will handle this detail
for us and the plan is to forward to him serum from cases in which
the Pfeiffer test is to be applied.

I agree with you that antimalarial work generally in con-
nection with the yellow fever campaign over as large an area as we
have here in Mexico is not practicable, notwithstanding that the
antimalarial measures which our men in Veracruz and Tampico have
carried out have on the whole been very successful.

I really believe that the Yellow Fever Council should re-
view our present campaign and a programme be developed for the future,
more especially now that Colombia and possibly Venezuela are a real
menace for reinfection of this country.

In the last year there seems to have developed in the mind
of some of the Politicians in Mexico that the present campaign is be-
ing continued for the benefit of the few. The trouble perhaps is due
to their regarding Guayaquil and Peru as typical examples of yellow
fever infected areas and reason that the rapidity with which the work
advanced should be duplicated in Mexico. It may be that the Consejo
have similar thoughts. Scannel writes me that Doctor Stubbs of Tampico
a long time resident in this country, and Miembro Asociado of the Com-
isión Especial, has stated that it will require twenty years to erad-
icate yellow fever from Mexico. It is these little things coming up
first in one section of the country and later in another section and
finally concentrating in a definite programme amongst the Politicians
to hold up appropriations for the work, this year the appropriation
for the Departamento de Salubridad Publica was long held up in the
Congress and it was only a few weeks ago that the budget for yellow
fever and malaria work amounting to $800,000 pesos was approved.

Personally I am sorry that Doctor Guiteras has resigned from
the Yellow Fever Council. He is a fearless man and would be a factor
for good on any Council. No doubt he was influenced by who Labredo
against Noguchi's Leptospira but the opposition serves as a stimulant
to urge other workers in the same field of endeavour to prove or dis-
prove the results of Noguchi's investigations.
Dr. Carter
June 5-1923

Regarding the legend of San Juan Bautista now Villaher-
mosa it appears that the city itself was noninfectible territory be-
cause of its complete water system serving an abundance of water to
all habiatations at all hours of the day or night and this system re-
mained in good condition and served the public from 1865 down to 1915,
this is according to the older residents of Villahermosa that I have
talked with. The water system has now been abandoned due to bad man-
agement of the Socialists. I have seen the plant and I was impressed
by it. There are a number of other small places in Tabasco that could
be classed as noninfectible areas from a campaign viewpoint but other-
wise no.

I think you have done well to bring up the point that an
animal may have been a reservoir host for the yellow fever infection.
This has long been in the minds of some investigators and while the
evidence for this belief is negative as yet, the suspicion shoudl be
cleared up if it is possible to do so.

Since my first visit to Yucatan and meeting up with the
archeologists there who are studying the monuments of the ancient
peoples the thought has been consatantly with me that our Board might
consider, if the matter was brought up to them, detailing a Paleopath-
ologist to work with the Archeologists and attempt to discover what
diseases afflicted the older races. The Archeologists tell me that
this field of research has never been properly developed and it is
their belief that rich knowledge awaits the concientous and patient
worker in this branch of research medicine.

From now on the ‘Jingo Press’ of Mexico will be carrying
sensational articles relative to the presence of yellow fever in this
and other parts of the Republic. Of course no attention should be giv-
en to these rumors but the Departamento believes, and I agree with them
that all reports of yellow fever_should be investigated and an earnest
effort is made to do this. The ‘El Mundo’ to which you referred to in
your letter is a sensational periodical and does lend itself, according
to rumors, in aiding certain interests.

I think you have done a great service in advising the
Surgeon General that the reports of the Comisión Especial will be un-
biased. Unfortunately your service sometimes has representatives here
who never make an inspection of the areas over which they are supposed
to maintain at least a nominal supervision. Therefore it is difficult
for us to actually show these men how the campaign is being carried on.
Pierce noted this when he was here, and I have the impression that he
will embody the observation in his report to the Surgeon General, in
fact, I understand he proposes to recommend that our men here act as
connecting links for the U. S. Public Health Service and the Departameno
de Salubridad Publica. I recommended against this plan to Doctor Russ-
ell for fear that it would involve our men in decisions on quarantine
matters and as you know none of our men here at the present time have
enough quarantine experience to permit them to act as advisors on these
questions.
Dr. Carter
June 5-1923

Doctor Walcott for the present is supervising the Sanitary
Inspectors in Merida and will remain there until the return of Doc-
tor Hernandez when I have in mind transferring Walcott, if agreable to
Doctor Scannell, to Tampico for the express purpose of making daily
rounds ofnthe hospitals and sanitariums in that city.
Doctor Walcott as you know is essentially a clinical man and the
above detail will admit of his applying his diagnostic ability.

Doctor Scannel writes me thatvin the event no case of
yellow fever developes in his area prior to August he will expect to be
detailed away from Mexico on the grounds that his services will no
longer be required. I wish I could agree with him and in a recent
letter to him I expressed the hope that the work in the Tampico Zone
would hold his interest until October at least at which time we will
be in a position to know more definitely the real conditions existing
in his area. I will bring to Tampico in August your Mss. on the his-
tory of yellow fever, at that time requesting him, when he will have
finished reading it to undertake getting it back to you.

Referring again to the chapter on epidemiology I wish that
it were possible to convey to you the great service that you have
rendered workers in the yellow fever field by writing on this phase
of yellow fever infection and placing the same at our disposal for
use.

It is the most complete work on the epidemiology of yellow fever I
have ever read and if I may make a suggestion it will be that our
Board would advise its men to study this chapter on epidemiology
and not merely read it because to use a slang expression “There is
meat in every line of the article”.

This letter brings to you the sincere thanks for all
kindly consideration which you have always shown me and the hope
that your prayer for the elimination (not controlled) of yellow fever
from Mexico and Central America this year be realized.
div1.closer:
With continued good wishes, I am
as always, very sincerely yours, M E Connor Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
